step_by_step_thinking: CD8+ T cells recognize antigens presented by MHC class I molecules on infected cells. The MHC class I complex consists of a heavy chain and β2-microglobulin (β2m), which are transported to the cell surface. The heavy chain binds endogenous peptides generated from intracellular pathogens (like HIV) via the TAP channel. The immunoprecipitated CD8-bound protein likely refers to the MHC class I complex, which presents these endogenous peptides. The two-chain structure matches the MHC class I heavy chain and β2m. This aligns with option C.
